summary: This document is an email chain from December 1, 2020, where a Daily Mail journalist, Stephen Wright, sends a list of questions about the DOJ's investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and its desire to interview Prince Andrew. The email is forwarded within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY, with a note that they decline to comment. It reveals ongoing media inquiry and public interest in Prince Andrew's status in the investigation.

persons.name: Stephen Wright
persons.context: Journalist for the Daily Mail in London who has reported on the Epstein scandal for nearly ten years; sends a list of questions to the U.S. Attorney's Office regarding the DOJ's investigation and Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: The Duke of York; the email questions focus on the DOJ's ongoing investigation, its desire to speak with him, and the terms of his potential testimony.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the sex trafficking scandal; the investigation into him and his alleged co-conspirators is the subject of the journalist's inquiry.

connections.description: The document references the DOJ's investigation into Epstein and its stated desire to speak with Prince Andrew in connection with it, implying an association under investigation.

events.title: Photo with alleged victim
events.description: Reference to a widely publicized picture purporting to show Prince Andrew with his arm around the waist of an alleged 17-year-old sex trafficking victim in London.

events.title: DOJ public statements and disputes
events.description: References public pronouncements by DOJ officials and claims by Prince Andrew's supporters about misleading statements and disputes over cooperation.

keyFacts: A Daily Mail journalist made a detailed inquiry to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY about the status of the DOJ's investigation and its efforts to interview Prince Andrew.

The inquiry includes six specific questions about whether an agreement for testimony has been reached, Prince Andrew's status as a 'witness' or 'subject', the location for an interview, and the authenticity of a controversial 2001 photograph.
The U.S. Attorney's Office declined to comment on all questions, as noted in the forwarding email.
The document confirms ongoing media and public interest in Prince Andrew's connection to the Epstein investigation as of late 2020.
